Abstract

In this work, the molecular enhancement factors of the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-odd interactions involving the electron electric dipole moment (Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and the scalar-pseudoscalar nucleon-electron couplings (Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) are computed for the ground state of the bimetallic molecules YbCu, YbAg and YbAu. These systems offer a promising venue for creating cold molecules by associating laser cooled atoms. The relativistic coupled-cluster approach is used in the calculations and a thorough uncertainty analysis is performed to give accurate and reliable uncertainties to the obtained values. Furthermore, an in-depth investigation of the different electronic structure effects that determine the magnitude of the calculated enhancement factors is carried out, and two different schemes for computing Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are compared. I Introduction

The current best description of elementary particles and their interactions is given by the Standard Model (SM) of particle physicsÂ [1]. This model is capable of explaining almost all experimental observations and of accurately predicting a wide range of diverse phenomena, which is why over time it has been consolidated as a well-tested physical theory. However, it does not address some important observed effects, such as the matter-antimatter asymmetry in the universe, the neutrino oscillations, and the existence and nature of dark matter and dark energyÂ [2, 3]. Over the past decades, many new theories and extensions of the SM have been proposed to explain these phenomenaÂ [3, 4]. Testing and restricting these theories is important for advancing our understanding of the fundamental laws of physics.

A promising way to test some of these theories is to search for effects due to the simultaneous non-conservation of spatial (ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P) and time-reversal (ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T) parities in atoms and molecules, such as those arising from the electric dipole moments (EDM) of electronsÂ [5]. Interactions between these EDMs and electromagnetic fields violate both temporal and spatial invarianceÂ [6]. Within a ğ’â¢ğ’«â¢ğ’¯ğ’ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{C}\mathcal{P}\mathcal{T}caligraphic_C caligraphic_P caligraphic_T-invariant theory (ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C refers to charge-conjugation symmetry), if ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T symmetry is violated, then the combined ğ’â¢ğ’«ğ’ğ’«\mathcal{CP}caligraphic_C caligraphic_P symmetry must also be non conserved, so that clearly ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T violation implies ğ’â¢ğ’«ğ’ğ’«\mathcal{CP}caligraphic_C caligraphic_P non conservationÂ [2].

The sources of ğ’â¢ğ’«ğ’ğ’«\mathcal{CP}caligraphic_C caligraphic_P violation described by the SM lead to the prediction of a free-electron EDM desubscriptğ‘‘ed_{\mathrm{e}}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of approximately 5.8Ã—10âˆ’40â¢eâ¢cm5.8superscript1040ğ‘’cm5.8\times 10^{-40}\,e\,\text{cm}5.8 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 40 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e cmÂ [7]. However, more sources of ğ’â¢ğ’«ğ’ğ’«\mathcal{CP}caligraphic_C caligraphic_P violation beyond those predicted by the SM are needed to explain, for example, the observed matter-antimatter asymmetry. The additional sources of ğ’â¢ğ’«ğ’ğ’«\mathcal{CP}caligraphic_C caligraphic_P violation would in turn lead to an increase in the magnitude of the electron EDM (eEDM), even bringing it into the reach of present day precision experimentsÂ [2]. Experimental searches for these phenomena are currently being carried out in atoms and molecules, taking advantage of the enhancement of the atomic and molecular EDMs. These arise from ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating interactions, mainly those taking place between the eEDMs and the large internal atomic or molecular electric fields, and also other ğ’â¢ğ’«ğ’ğ’«\mathcal{CP}caligraphic_C caligraphic_P-odd nucleon-electron and nucleon-nucleon interactionsÂ [8, 9, 10, 2]. Currently, the lowest upper limit of the eEDM is set at |de|<2.1Ã—10âˆ’29â¢eâ¢cmsubscriptğ‘‘e2.1superscript1029ğ‘’cm|d_{\mathrm{e}}|<2.1\times 10^{-29}\,e\,\text{cm}| italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | < 2.1 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 29 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e cm. This upper limit was reported after measurements conducted by the National Institute of Science and Technology (NIST) on the HfF+ molecular ionÂ [11], and combining these results with those obtained by the ACME Collaboration in their analysis of the ThO moleculeÂ [12]. It is important to stress that if ğ’â¢ğ’«ğ’ğ’«\mathcal{CP}caligraphic_C caligraphic_P violation is assumed to arise exclusively from desubscriptğ‘‘ed_{\mathrm{e}}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the NIST experiment (i.e., if the scalar-pseudoscalar nucleon-electron couplings are neglected), then the upper limit would be |de|<4.1Ã—10âˆ’30â¢eâ¢cmsubscriptğ‘‘e4.1superscript1030ğ‘’cm|d_{\mathrm{e}}|<4.1\times 10^{-30}\,e\,\text{cm}| italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | < 4.1 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 30 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e cm. This lowest upper limit has already put considerable constraints on some of the theories beyond the SMÂ [13, 14].

In the ground state of a molecule with zero nuclear spins and a single unpaired electron there are two main contributions to its energy arising from ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating interactions. These arise from the interactions between the EDMs of the electrons and the electromagnetic fields, and from the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-odd scalar-pseudoscalar nucleon-electron (S-PS-ne) neutral-current interactionsÂ [15, 9]. Since the effects of the eEDM and the S-PS-ne interactions are enhanced by the molecular electronic structure, the two corresponding molecular enhancement factors Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (related to desubscriptğ‘‘ed_{\mathrm{e}}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which enhances the S-PS-ne interactions) are of particular interest.

The choice of molecule for the measurements has a significant impact on the sensitivity due to, among others, the system-dependent enhancement of the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-odd effects. Since in paramagnetic molecules containing only one heavy element this enhancement scales roughly as the cube of the atomic number of the heavier nucleus to which the unpaired electron is strongly linked toÂ [16, 17], some heavy-element-containing molecules have an advantage over other systems. Furthermore, practical experimental considerations play a crucial role in selecting a candidate for experiments. For example, the use of ultracold molecules increases interaction times and hence the experimental precisionÂ [18]. Therefore, laser-coolability of the selected molecule provides a clear advantage. Various molecular properties relevant for precision measurements (e.g., laser coolability and sensitivity to the measured phenomena, but also many others) can be determined theoretically before experimental investigations in support of such experiments. In particular, the enhancement factors cannot be measured and must be provided based on accurate electronic structure calculations.

In this work, we investigate the sensitivity of the YbCu, YbAg and YbAu paramagnetic molecules to ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating phenomena. These systems are of particular interest, since they contain two metal atoms. Theoretically, this means that these atoms can be laser-cooled separately and then associated into a molecule afterwards, eliminating the need to laser-cool the molecule as a wholeÂ [19, 20]. So far, laser-cooling of Yb and Ag atoms has been demonstratedÂ [21, 22]. Laser-cooling of Cu and Au has not been demonstrated yet, but cooling schemes have been proposedÂ [23]. Furthermore, these polar molecules have large molecular-frame electric dipole moments, due to the large electronegativity of the coinage-metal atoms, allowing for their easy polarization. In particular, YbAg is considered as a promising candidate for a next generation clock-transition eEDM measurementÂ [20].

No experiments have been performed so far on YbCu, YbAg or YbAu, but several experimental groups pursue ultracold formation of other Ag-containing moleculesÂ [24, 25, 26, 27]. However, high-accuracy calculations of the potential energy curves, molecular-frame electric dipole moments, electric quadrupole moments, and static electric dipole polarizabilities of the present systems were recently performedÂ [28]. Here we employ the four-component (4C) relativistic coupled-cluster (CC) approach to calculate the enhancement factors of the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating interactions between the eEDMs and the electric fields in the systems, Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and of the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-odd S-PS-ne interactions, Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The enhancement factors are determined for the ground states, X2â¢Î£12+superscriptğ‘‹2subscriptsuperscriptÎ£12X\,^{2}\Sigma^{+}_{\frac{1}{2}}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, of the three molecules. We also carry out an extensive computational study to assign uncertainties on the calculated values.

In paramagnetic systems containing at least one non-zero nuclear spin Iğ¼Iitalic_I, some internal nuclear interactions lead to nuclear spin-dependent molecular ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating effects, such as magnetic interactions between the electrons and the nuclear magnetic quadrupole moment (NMQM), which appears for nuclear spin Iâ‰¥1ğ¼1I\geq 1italic_I â‰¥ 1Â [29, 30]. These effects are, however, outside the scope of this work.

SectionÂ II covers the main theoretical aspects of this work, detailing how both enhancement factors can be obtained from effective Hamiltonians. Then, SectionÂ III contains a description of the methods employed to calculate these factors, as well as the scheme use for geometry optimization. Next, SectionÂ IV presents the obtained enhancement factors and their dependence on effects such as the choice of the nuclear charge density model, the method for treatment of electron correlation, the choice of the basis set, and the internuclear distances. Finally, SectionÂ V contains a concise summary of our findings.

II Theory

The ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating interactions involving the EDMs of atoms or molecules produce non-zero linear Stark shifts in the limit of vanishingly small applied electric fields. These interactions originate from many different sources, but mainly from the EDMs of electrons and nucleons, as well as from the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating nucleon-nucleon current interactions and the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-odd electronâ€“quark interactionsÂ [31]. In particular, for paramagnetic linear molecules in X2â¢Î£12superscriptğ‘‹2subscriptÎ£12X\,^{2}\Sigma_{\frac{1}{2}}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ground states, such as the systems treated in this paper, the interactions between eEDMs and electromagnetic fields and the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-odd S-PS-ne neutral-current interactions dominateÂ [32]. In these cases, the effective spin-rotation Hamiltonian that includes only nuclear-spin-independent ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-odd interactions (i.e., neglecting the interactions between electrons and NMQMs) can be written asÂ [9, 33]

To compute the enhancement factors, the effects of the eEDM and the S-PS-ne interactions are taken as perturbations on the 4C relativistic Diracâ€“Coulomb (DC) Hamiltonian. II.1 eEDM enhancement factor Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

The effects on hydrogenic atoms arising from a ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-odd interaction between the permanent EDM of a single electron, parallel to its spin, and an electromagnetic field has been studied for the first time by Salpeter in 1958Â [34]. In his seminal work, he introduced a ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-odd perturbation term corresponding to a permanent eEDM into the one-electron Dirac equation in a Lorentz-covariant formulation. This term is analogous to the so-called â€œPauli momentâ€ interaction term (representing a QED interaction of the lowest order, for non-relativistic energies, between the electromagnetic field and the Pauli anomalous electric and magnetic dipole moments of the electron), but pre-multiplied by the pseudoscalar Dirac operator Î³5superscriptğ›¾5\gamma^{5}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see pp.Â 47â€“51 of Ref.Â 35).

In atoms or molecules with at least one electron whose spin is unpaired, the effects arising from these ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating interactions produce atomic or molecular (permanent) ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating electric dipole moments that may be significantly larger than that of a free electron. In the past it has been shown that the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating EDM of these many-electron systems is mainly influenced by the electrostatic interactions between the eEDM of the unpaired electron and the internal electric fieldsÂ [36]. Therefore, when calculating the molecular enhancement parameter Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Eq.Â (1)) it is possible to ignore effects such as the interactions between the eEDM and the magnetic fields, and also the electron-electron Breit interactions.

When neglecting both, the interactions of the eEDMs with internal and external magnetic fields and the Breit interactions, the mean value of the Salpeter Hamiltonian can be equated to the expectation value of two different operators. One of these two effective Hamiltonians is the sum of only one-electron operators, while the other one also contains two-body operators. These two-electron contributions, however, have been shown to be considerably smaller than the one-electron ones in that particular effective Hamiltonian, and as such they can usually be safely neglectedÂ [8, 36].

Therefore, by employing any of these two effective Hamiltonians (denoted henceforth as scheme 1 and scheme 2) to make theoretical predictions, one avoids having to treat the two-electron interactions of the Salpeter Hamiltonian, which are not negligible. The first of these effective Hamiltonians (i.e., within scheme 1) has the form

Scheme 2 contains only one-electron operators within an approximation in which both the magnetic interactions and the electron-electron Breit interactions are neglected, reducing the computational complexity. However, a drawback of this effective Hamiltonian is in the fact that the non-relativistic limit of its mean value is not zero, while that of the Salpeter Hamiltonian vanishesÂ [38]. Furthermore, scheme 2 does not allow analysis of the separate nuclear contributions to the calculated Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT parameters. Within scheme 1, on the other hand, the the non-relativistic limit of Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is zero. While scheme 1 includes two-electron contributions (see Eq.Â (6)), these are much smaller than the corresponding one-electron counterpartsÂ [36, 16] and can usually be neglected. Therefore, scheme 1 allows us to study the effective contributions to Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT arising from each nucleus of the system, keeping the correct non-relativistic behavior, and using only one-electron operators.

III Computational details

The calculations were performed using the DIRAC-19.0 program packageÂ [40, 41], in the framework of the 4C DC Hamiltonian. The multi-reference Fock-space coupled-cluster (FSCC) method with single and double excitations was used to treat electron correlation effectsÂ [42]. A multi-reference method is required due to the challenging character of the ytterbium-containing moleculesÂ [43, 44]. This method was employed previously to study the enhancement factors of the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating interactions in YbOHÂ [45] and YbCH3Â [46]. Additionally, we also used the FSCC implementation within the EXP-T programÂ [47, 48] to investigate the effects of including triple excitations.

The uncontracted Dyallâ€™s valence-only basis sets of double-Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶ (v2z), triple-Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶ (v3z) and quadruple-Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶ (v4z) quality were employedÂ [49, 50, 51, 52, 53]. Furthermore, the core-valence basis sets (cvXğ‘‹Xitalic_Xz, X=2,3,4ğ‘‹234X=2,3,4italic_X = 2 , 3 , 4) were also used in order to examine the effect of correlating the core electronsÂ [54]. These particular basis sets add tight functions with large exponents. The augmented basis sets (s-aug-vXğ‘‹Xitalic_Xz) were employed to investigate how accurately the outer regions of the systems were described. These basis sets add a single diffuse function to each symmetry block.

III.1 Finite-field method

III.2 Geometry optimization

The enhancement factors were computed for the equilibrium geometries of the systems. The bond lengths were determined using the exact two component (X2C) HamiltonianÂ [55], the single-reference CCSD method, and s-aug-v4z basis sets. By employing the X2C Hamiltonian, the Dirac equation is transformed decoupling the large and small components of the Dirac spinors. This method only takes positive energy solutions into account. The active space energy cut-offs for the virtual (unoccupied) and occupied orbitals were set to Â±20â¢Ehplus-or-minus20subscriptğ¸â„\pm 20\,E_{h}Â± 20 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Â±10â¢Ehplus-or-minus10subscriptğ¸â„\pm 10\,E_{h}Â± 10 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Â±10â¢Ehplus-or-minus10subscriptğ¸â„\pm 10\,E_{h}Â± 10 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, respectively. A smaller active space was used for the heavier molecules since computing their bond distances is computationally more intensive. The results of these geometry optimizations can be found in Table 1 along with the values obtained previously in Ref.Â 28.

The general trend observed for both sets of results is that the bond length increases from YbCu to YbAg and then decreases from YbAg to YbAu, likely due to the relativistic contraction of the 6sğ‘ sitalic_s orbital of gold. A non-relativistic treatment would show longer bonds for heavier systemsÂ [56].

The discrepancy between the present and the previous values is likely due to the use of pseudopotentials (especially a large-core one with a core polarization potential for Yb) in the latter. ECPs are limited to scalar-relativistic effects, while the X2C procedure employed here also accounts for the spin-orbit coupling. The fact that the largest discrepancy is found for the heavier system supports this assumption.

IV Results and discussion

To obtain accurate enhancement factors accompanied by well-defined uncertainties, multiple computational aspects will be addressed. For all the calculations discussed in this section, the 4C DC Hamiltonian was employed. First, the baseline results will be presented in SectionÂ IV.1. Then, the effect of selecting two different nuclear charge density distribution models is examined for both factors in SectionÂ IV.2. Furthermore, the two schemes employed for computing Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be compared in SectionÂ IV.3. Next, the influence of the basis set will be determined in SectionÂ IV.4. Thereafter, different computational approaches will be compared in SectionÂ IV.5. Finally, the effect of the geometry of the system on Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be discussed in SectionÂ IV.6.

This extensive investigation allows us to set uncertainties on the recommended values. The justification for the final results and their uncertainties will be given in SectionÂ IV.7.

IV.1 Baseline calculations

All the reference values for Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were computed on the v3z/FSCCSD level. For YbCu and YbAg, a virtual space cut-off of 500â¢Eh500subscriptğ¸â„500\,E_{h}500 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was employed, and 2 and 4 electrons were frozen, respectively. For YbAu, the virtual space cut-off was set to 40â¢Eh40subscriptğ¸â„40\,E_{h}40 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and 56 electrons were frozen. The selection of these correlation parameters is justified in the Supplementary Material.

The calculated enhancement factors for the three systems are given in Table 2. We can observe that both parameters are very similar for YbCu and YbAg, while much lower absolute values are obtained for YbAu. This finding will be elucidated in the following sections. Furthermore, multiple corrections to these baseline values will be determined. The final obtained values will be given in SectionÂ IV.7.

For YbCu and YbAg, the results using GN are âˆ¼1.1%similar-toabsentpercent1.1\sim 1.1\%âˆ¼ 1.1 % smaller than those obtained employing PN, while for YbAu the GN result is âˆ¼9.2%similar-toabsentpercent9.2\sim 9.2\%âˆ¼ 9.2 % larger than the one using a PN.

FigureÂ 2 shows the nuclear size effects on Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The contributions from each of the nuclei are shown, as well as the total values of Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, represented by hatched blocks. The contributions associated with the nuclei of the coinage metals become increasingly important as their atomic number increases. Moreover, as expected, these contributions are of opposite sign to those of ytterbium, because in the region between the two nuclei the gradients of the nuclear densities have opposite directions. For YbAu, the two contributions almost cancel each other out, leading to a very small total value of Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In all three cases, the contribution of the ytterbium nucleus is reduced by âˆ¼13%similar-toabsentpercent13\sim 13\%âˆ¼ 13 % when going from PN to GN, while for copper, silver, and gold the reduction is âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼Â 0.16%percent0.160.16\%0.16 %, âˆ¼3.5%similar-toabsentpercent3.5\sim 3.5\%âˆ¼ 3.5 %, and âˆ¼20%similar-toabsentpercent20\sim 20\%âˆ¼ 20 %, respectively. Thus, the effect of using a finite nucleus model becomes more significant for the heavier elements, as can be expected. The total absolute Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is also lower for the calculations performed using the GN model.

IV.3 Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: Comparison of schemes 1 and 2

It is well known that when only the electric field produced by the nuclei is taken into account in scheme 1, the two schemes described in SectionÂ II.1 should yield similar results for Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPTÂ [36]. While the use of scheme 2 is computationally less demanding, since it requires just a single calculation per system instead of the two that are required for each diatomic molecule, scheme 1 allows us to examine the effective contributions arising from each nucleus. In order to study those individual contributions, in this work we present (to the best of our knowledge) the first four-component results of Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the approximate effective Hamiltonian of Eq.Â (10), corresponding to the use of scheme 1.

The enhancement factors Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were computed using both schemes for the three systems considered in this work, on the FSCCSD/v2z level of theory, with symmetric cut-offs of 500â¢Eh500subscriptğ¸â„500\,E_{h}500 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 500â¢Eh500subscriptğ¸â„500\,E_{h}500 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and 40â¢Eh40subscriptğ¸â„40\,E_{h}40 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, freezing 2, 4, and 56 electrons of YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, respectively. The calculations were only performed using a PN model (and not a GN nucleus), since some integrals required for scheme 1 for finite nuclear models, despite having been studied using two-component methodsÂ [16], are currently not implemented in DIRAC.

FigureÂ 3 shows the difference in Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when computed with the two schemes for the three systems. The total YbCu Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT calculated using scheme 2 is âˆ¼1.5%similar-toabsentpercent1.5\sim 1.5\%âˆ¼ 1.5 % smaller than the scheme 1 result. For YbAg, this difference is âˆ¼1.4%similar-toabsentpercent1.4\sim 1.4\%âˆ¼ 1.4 %. For YbAu, the reduction is âˆ¼4.7%similar-toabsentpercent4.7\sim 4.7\%âˆ¼ 4.7 %.

Using scheme 1, it can be seen that the contributions to Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the Yb nucleus remain almost constant for all three systems. Moreover, the contributions from the coinage metals all have opposite signs to those coming from Yb, as is the case for the Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT factors. This is expected, since the electric fields due to the two nuclei in the internuclear region have opposite directions, and according to Eqs.Â (9) and (10), this generates opposite contributions to this enhancement parameter. The decreasing total Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT factor from YbCu to YbAu is due to the increasing contribution from the second nucleus (opposite to that of the first).

IV.4 Basis set effects

To observe how the size of the basis set influences the enhancement factors, Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were computed with double-Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶, triple-Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶ and quadruple-Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶ quality basis sets. These calculations were done using the FSCCSD method, and the (occupied and virtual) active space cut-offs were set to Â±20â¢Ehplus-or-minus20subscriptğ¸â„\pm 20\,E_{h}Â± 20 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Â±10â¢Ehplus-or-minus10subscriptğ¸â„\pm 10\,E_{h}Â± 10 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Â±10â¢Ehplus-or-minus10subscriptğ¸â„\pm 10\,E_{h}Â± 10 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, freezing 38, 64 and 82 electrons of YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, respectively.

The plot in FigureÂ 4 shows the effect of increasing the basis set cardinality on Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Converging behavior can be observed for parameter values with increasing basis set quality for YbCu and YbAg. While no apparent convergence can be observed for the total Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values of YbAu, this convergence can be seen by looking at the individual contributions in Figure 5. A similar trend is expected for Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Apart from adding contributing functions to all orbitals, it is also possible to add only tight or diffuse functions. Tight functions should increase the accuracy of the description of the core region of the system, while diffuse functions should improve the accuracy of the description of the valence region of the system. The cvXğ‘‹Xitalic_Xz basis sets contain higher angular momentum tight functions, and the s-aug-vXğ‘‹Xitalic_Xz basis sets augment a diffuse function to the vXğ‘‹Xitalic_Xz basis set. These computations were done using the same computational settings as the ones above.

The effects of increasing the accuracy on the description of the core and valence regions of the systems is small for both enhancement factors. Adding tight functions has a negligible effect on all three systems for Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (with the largest change of 0.005Ã—1024â¢hâ¢Hzeâ¢cm0.005superscript1024â„Hzğ‘’cm0.005\times 10^{24}\frac{h\,\text{Hz}}{e\,\text{cm}}0.005 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 24 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_h Hz end_ARG start_ARG italic_e cm end_ARG) and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (with the largest change of 0.024â¢hâ¢kHz0.024â„kHz0.024~{}h\,\text{kHz}0.024 italic_h kHz). On the other hand, adding diffuse functions reduces the parameter values slightly (with the largest changes of 0.033Ã—1024â¢hâ¢Hzeâ¢cm0.033superscript1024â„Hzğ‘’cm0.033\times 10^{24}\frac{h\,\text{Hz}}{e\,\text{cm}}0.033 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 24 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_h Hz end_ARG start_ARG italic_e cm end_ARG and 0.143â¢hâ¢kHz0.143â„kHz0.143~{}h\,\text{kHz}0.143 italic_h kHz for Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively). Furthermore, the enhancement factors of the YbAg system are more affected than those of YbCu. For YbAu, the addition of diffuse functions increases the calculated Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and decreases the Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Still, the relative effects remain within 3%percent33\%3 % of the total value, as can be seen in the Supplementary Material.

For the final calculations, the v3z basis set was used. For all the calculated enhancement factors, the differences between the use of v4z and v3z basis sets is small compared to the electron correlation effects. The incompleteness of the basis set will be taken into account in the uncertainty.

IV.5 Computational methods

The method used so far throughout this work for calculations of the enhancement factors is 4C Diracâ€“Coulomb FSCC.

In Table 3 and Figures 6 and 7, different approaches are compared: DHF, MÃ¸llerâ€“Plesset up to second order (MP2), FSCCSD and FSCCSDT. These calculations were performed employing the dyall.v2z basis set, and the active space cut-offs for the post-DHF computations were set to Â±2â¢Ehplus-or-minus2subscriptğ¸â„\pm 2\,E_{h}Â± 2 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, freezing 66, 84 and 116 electrons of YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, respectively. This small active space was chosen because inclusion of triple excitations (using the EXP-T program) is computationally expensive. The DHF results differ the most from the FSCC values, while the MP2 values are close to the CC results for YbCu and YbAg. On the other hand, going from MP2 to FSCC reduced the value of Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for YbAu by a factor of two and reverses the sign of Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Including the triple excitations in the FSCC calculations has only a minor effect on the enhancement factors of YbCu and YbAg, but increases the Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and decreases the Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of YbAu significantly, in line with enhanced sensitivity of this systems to the other computational parameters. The differences between the FSCCSD and FSCCSDT methods will be used to estimate the uncertainty due to neglect of the higher excitations in SectionÂ IV.7.

IV.6 Influence of molecular geometry

IV.6.1 Uncertainty associated to the bond length

The equilibrium bond lengths used in the calculations of the enhancement factors are given in SectionÂ III.2. The accuracy of these theoretically predicted values compared to experiments is unknown, since no experimental bond lengths are available for the systems considered in this work. Since the bond length has a significant impact on the studied enhancement factors, the uncertainty associated to the bond length should be taken into account. The difference between the calculated equilibrium bond lengths obtained within the FSCCSD approach and the experimental values is usually on the order of 0.01Â Ã…times0.01angstrom0.01\text{\,}\mathrm{\text{Ã…}}start_ARG 0.01 end_ARG start_ARG times end_ARG start_ARG angstrom end_ARGÂ [58].

All enhancement factors were computed at the calculated equilibrium bond distances, as well as at 0.01Â Ã…times0.01angstrom0.01\text{\,}\mathrm{\text{Ã…}}start_ARG 0.01 end_ARG start_ARG times end_ARG start_ARG angstrom end_ARG larger and smaller internuclear distances. These computations were performed on the FSCCSD/v2z level of theory, and the (occupied and virtual) active space cut-offs were set to Â±100â¢Ehplus-or-minus100subscriptğ¸â„\pm 100\,E_{h}Â± 100 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Â±100â¢Ehplus-or-minus100subscriptğ¸â„\pm 100\,E_{h}Â± 100 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Â±95â¢Ehplus-or-minus95subscriptğ¸â„\pm 95\,E_{h}Â± 95 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, freezing 12, 20 and 28 electrons of YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, respectively. The results are given in TableÂ 4.

For both enhancement factors of YbCu and YbAg, the result decreases by only 0.1âˆ’0.2%0.1percent0.20.1-0.2\%0.1 - 0.2 % for the larger internuclear distance and increases only by 0.1âˆ’0.2%0.1percent0.20.1-0.2\%0.1 - 0.2 % for the smaller internuclear distance. For YbAu, the deviation is significantly larger, at 5.0âˆ’7.0%5.0percent7.05.0-7.0\%5.0 - 7.0 %.

IV.6.2 Vibrational corrections

The anharmonicity of the potential energy curve for the electronic ground state implies that the effective equilibrium bond distance is shifted slightly compared to the minimum of the potential energy curve. This slight difference in bond length results in small changes in the enhancement factors.

To compute the vibrational correction, calculations of the enhancement factors and the potential energies for different bond lengths were performed. The results for Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, split up into the contribution arising from each nucleus, can be found in FigureÂ 8. These values are given as a function of the difference between the internuclear distances and the equilibrium bond length of the corresponding molecule (in Angstroms). The resulting Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values are given as a percentage compared to the results found at the equilibrium bond length. It can be seen that the coinage metal contribution is significantly more sensitive to the bond length effect compared to the Yb contribution. This is also in accordance to the sensitivity of the respective atoms to the description of the electronic structure, as can be seen in FigureÂ 7.

The correction values were computed using the VIBCAL module in DIRAC-19.0, using a fourth-order polynomial for the energy fitting. The vibrational corrections are listed in TableÂ 5 for both enhancement factors.

The vibrational corrections alter the original values (obtained at Resubscriptğ‘…ğ‘’R_{e}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) at most by âˆ¼1%similar-toabsentpercent1\sim 1\%âˆ¼ 1 %. These differences will also be taken into account when computing the final values in SectionÂ IV.7.

IV.7 Final recommended values and uncertainties

The baseline results given in SectionÂ IV.1 can now be corrected to obtain the final recommended values of Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The contributions resulting from using a larger basis set (dyall.v4z), correlating all electrons, increasing the virtual space cut-offs, including triple excitations, and taking into account vibrational corrections were added to the reference baseline values. TableÂ 6 presents these different contributions and also the final recommended values.

In particular, the basis set corrections were calculated as differences between FSCCSD calculations with active space cut-offs of Â±20â¢Ehplus-or-minus20subscriptğ¸â„\pm 20\,E_{h}Â± 20 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for YbCu and Â±10â¢Ehplus-or-minus10subscriptğ¸â„\pm 10\,E_{h}Â± 10 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for YbAg and YbAu, employing the dyall.v4z and dyall.v3z basis sets (see Table VI of the Supplementary Material).

The effects arising from correlating all electrons were taken as the differences between freezing 2, 4 and 56 electrons for YbCu, YbAg and YbAu respectively and correlating all the electrons and simultaneously increasing the virtual cutoff to 6000â¢Eh6000subscriptğ¸â„6000\,E_{h}6000 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at the FSCCSD/dyall.v2z level of theory. A detailed analysis of the effects of the active correlation space size is available in the Supplementary Material.

The effects due to the inclusion of higher excitations were taken as the differences between FSCCSDT and FSCCSD calculations, employing v2z basis sets and cut-offs of Â±2â¢Ehplus-or-minus2subscriptğ¸â„\pm 2\,E_{h}Â± 2 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally, the vibrational effects were extracted from TableÂ 5.

To estimate conservative and reliable uncertainties for these values, a similar treatment to that given in Refs.Â 59 and 46 will be employed. The individual uncertainties obtained from the considerations discussed in the previous sections are given in Table 7, graphically displayed in FigureÂ 9, and analyzed in the following subsections.

IV.7.1 Basis set

The uncertainty due to the basis set has three different sources: (i) the general quality of the basis set, (ii) the quality of the treatment of tight functions, and (iii) the quality of the treatment of diffuse functions.

The uncertainties in the general quality of the basis sets are due to the fact that the values possibly have not converged yet at the v4z level. The baseline values are corrected by adding the difference between the v4z and v3z results, as found in SectionÂ IV.4. For all parameters, the uncertainties in basis set quality are taken as a half of the differences between v4z and v3z results, to account for the unconsidered effects arising from the use of larger basis sets.

The uncertainties due to the possible insufficient amount of tight functions are given by the differences between the cv3z and the v3z results. Finally, the differences between the s-aug-v3z and v3z results determine the uncertainties in the quality of diffuse function treatment.

IV.7.2 Electron correlation

Electron correlation is affected by the chosen (occupied and virtual) active space cut-offs, along with the excitations taken into account.

To account for the frozen orbitals in the baseline calculation, the results provided in the Supplementary Material are used. The difference in enhancement factors between correlating all electrons, and freezing 2, 4 and 56 electrons for YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, respectively, was used to correct the baseline values.

The correction from the employed virtual space cut-off is given by the differences between the obtained values at a virtual space cut-off of 6000â¢Eh6000subscriptğ¸â„6000\,E_{h}6000 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the values found using an active space cut-off of Â±3000â¢Ehplus-or-minus3000subscriptğ¸â„\pm 3000\,E_{h}Â± 3000 italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To account for the effect of higher lying virtual orbitals, half of this difference is taken as an additional uncertainty.

The baseline values do not take into account CC triple excitations. The differences between the results obtained using the FSCCSDT and the FSCCSD methods, as given in SectionÂ IV.5, were used to correct for this omission. Since these results may not be fully converged yet, the effect of including triple excitations is used to estimate the uncertainty arising from not including quadruple and higher excitations. The obtained differences between the FSCCSDT and FSCCSD results is multiplied one half to account for the uncertainty due to excitations involving more than three electrons.

IV.7.3 Geometry

The bond length uncertainty contributes to the enhancement factor uncertainty due to the geometry of the systems. To estimate the uncertainty due to the bond length, the enhancement factors were computed for internuclear distances 0.01Â Ã…times0.01angstrom0.01\text{\,}\mathrm{\text{Ã…}}start_ARG 0.01 end_ARG start_ARG times end_ARG start_ARG angstrom end_ARG larger and smaller than the calculated Resubscriptğ‘…ğ‘’R_{e}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The largest deviations from the parameters at equilibrium bond lengths were taken as their uncertainties.

The vibrational corrections obtained in SectionÂ IV.6.2 are applied to the baseline values, as can be seen in Table 6.

IV.7.4 Sum of atomic Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\text{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation

Due to the fact that the interaction constants ks,Ksubscriptğ‘˜sğ¾k_{\mathrm{s},K}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s , italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eq.Â (17) are specific to each nucleus, calculating the total Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\text{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT value as a sum of the atomic contribution is only approximate and introduces an associated error. We analyze this error in detail in an upcoming publication [60]. Here, we provide the resulting uncertainties of 0.059, 0.308 and 1.318Â hâ„hitalic_hÂ kHz for YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, respectively. We note that the specific errors differ for each isotopologue. Therefore, here we use the isotopic average weighted by the natural abundances of all constituting elements.

IV.7.5 Total uncertainty

To compute the total uncertainties for the reference values of the enhancement factors of YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, the Euclidean norm of the individual uncertainties is taken. These total uncertainties are obtained on the assumption that the different contributions are largely independent, since they concern high order effects.

The relative uncertainties of Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (0.33%percent0.330.33\%0.33 %, 0.63%percent0.630.63\%0.63 % and 22.74%percent22.7422.74\%22.74 %, for YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, respectively) are larger than those found for Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (0.13%percent0.130.13\%0.13 %, 0.61%percent0.610.61\%0.61 % and 13.12%percent13.1213.12\%13.12 %, for YbCu, YbAg and YbAu, respectively). For these systems, the enhancement factors are dominated by the uncertainty due to missing higher CC excitations and, to a smaller degree, by the basis set incompleteness, as illustrated in Figure 9.

The results for YbAu have significantly higher relative uncertainty than the other two systems. Both enhancement factors of this system are relatively small, due to a cancellation of similar sized contributions from the two constituent atoms, rendering them unstable and very sensitive to the computational settings and leading to a large relative uncertainty. The calculated Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of YbCu and YbAg have remarkably small uncertainties of less than a single percent. For comparison, similar computational approach yielded uncertainties of 3 âˆ’-- 7% for the enhancement factors of BaF [59], YbCH3 [46], and LuO [61]. The lower uncertainty in the current case is partly due to the fact that we have corrected our results for the triple excitations, in contrast to the earlier works, where the missing excitations beyond doubles are a major source of uncertainty.

IV.8 Comparison to other systems

The calculated enhancement factors are compared to those found for other ytterbium-containing molecules in Table 8. Additionally, some of the systems currently used in experiments aiming to restrict the upper limit on the eEDM were added. The Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT factors of YbCu and YbAg are of similar magnitude to those found for YbOH, YbCH3 and YbF. Both enhancement factors of YbAu are significantly smaller than those found for any other ytterbium-containing system.

Since both the interactions of the eEDMs with electromagnetic fields and the S-PS-ne neutral-current interactions may contribute to an eventual experimental detection of ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating effects in molecules, these two type of interactions should be decoupled from each other. This can be done by performing measurements on systems with different enhancement factor ratios [16]. For the systems studied in this work, and some other molecules currently and previously under investigation, these ratios can be calculated from the values of enhancement factors reported in Table 8.

V Conclusion

In order to extract information about the ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating effects arising from both the interactions between eEDMs and electromagnetic fields and the S-PS-ne neutral-current interactions from precision experiments in paramagnetic polar molecules containing only non-zero nuclear spins, the enhancement factors Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have to be obtained through molecular electronic structure computations. In this work, these parameters were computed for the YbCu, YbAg and YbAu systems, selected due to their possible experimental advantages. The enhancement factors Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were calculated using two different schemes, and here we report (to the best of our knowledge) the first 4C computations using scheme 1. Besides, a thorough uncertainty analysis was performed to assign a conservative error on the obtained results.

The recommended values were calculated using the FSCC method and the 4C DC Hamiltonian in conjunction with relativistic basis sets. The main contributing sources of uncertainty are due to the limited basis set sizes and the neglect of CC excitations beyond triples.

The obtained enhancement factors of YbCu and YbAg are of very similar size to other Yb-containing compounds investigated in the literature. In case of YbAu, the cancellation of the contributions arising from the two nuclei in the system leads to vanishingly small total Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values. For YbCu and YbAg, the results are also of similar size as for other systems currently investigated experimentally to search for signs of ğ’«,ğ’¯ğ’«ğ’¯\mathcal{P,T}caligraphic_P , caligraphic_T-violating effects. Compared to YbF and YbOH, the alternate method of producing and cooling these systems provides an alternative route for future experiments setting a lowest upper limit on the eEDM.

Supplementary Material

In the Supplementary Material we analyze the influence of the active space (in particular, of the energy of occupied and virtual correlated orbitals) on the calculation of Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also present a set of tables where we report the values of these parameters using different nuclear models, different schemes corresponding to the use of the two effective Hamiltonians described in this work (for the case of Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and a few different basis sets. In addition, tables are provided showing the dependence of the molecular enhancement factors on the use of different methods to treat electron correlation, on vibrational effects, and also the contributions to Wdsubscriptğ‘ŠdW_{\mathrm{d}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wssubscriptğ‘ŠsW_{\mathrm{s}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT associated with each nucleus of the studied molecular systems.
